sec.title: The National Institute for Health and Welfare in Finland (THL)
Patients living alone have a higher risk of heart attack
sec.p: Marriage significantly reduces the risk of acute coronary events among both men and women. A recent study, co-ordinated by THL and carried out in collaboration with several hospitals in Finland, also reveals that prognosis of acute coronary events is worse in patients living alone.

The incidence of acute coronary events was, on average, 1.6 times higher in unmarried men and women than in married men and women. Also, the 28-day mortality rate was, on average, 2.1 times higher among unmarried men and women. Most deaths occurred before hospitalization.
The morbidity and mortality data was collected from the population-based FINAMI myocardial infarction register and the study sample consisted of 15 330 acute coronary events in 1993–2002.
Prognosis of acute coronary events is worse in patients living alone: the FINAMI myocardial infarction register http://cpr.sagepub.com/content/early/2013/01/29/2047487313475893

sec.title: Long-term psychotherapy gives more sustained benefits than short-term therapy
sec.p: A recent study followed 326 outpatients with mood or anxiety disorder for five years during 1995-2000. The patients were randomly assigned to three types of therapy: 3-year long-term psychodynamic psychotherapy, short-term half-year psychodynamic therapy and short-term solution-focused therapy.

The rate of recovery from psychiatric symptoms and the work ability improvement rate remained higher in the long-term therapy group 5 years after the start of therapy, whereas no differences were found in the effectiveness of the two short-term therapies.
The present results were obtained in a randomized clinical trial with an exceptionally long follow-up. The findings suggest the need for a careful evaluation of the suitability of short-term therapy.
The Helsinki Psychotherapy Study is led by THL and carried out in collaboration with several institutions and hospitals.

Knekt P, Lindfors O, Sares-Jäske L, Virtala E, Härkänen T. Randomized trial on the effectiveness of long- and short-term psychotherapy on psychiatric symptoms and working ability during a 5-year follow-up. Nord J Psychiatry 2013; 67: 59-68. http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/08039488.2012.680910

sec.title: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health
Can environmental contaminants cause lower sperm count?
sec.p: The amount of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) that mothers had in their blood during pregnancy was correlated with their sons’ semen quality at 20 years old. These findings appear in a recent study from Aarhus University Hospital, Denmark, in which the Norwegian Institute of Public Health participated.

sec.title: Environmental contaminants may reduce immunity
sec.p: Exposure to environmental contaminants during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of infections during the first three years of life and a reduced response to childhood vaccines. This is found in two studies from the Norwegian Mother and Child Cohort Study (MoBa) at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health.
